item.title: “I can’t blame them, but I think it caught us all off guard...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“I can’t blame them, but I think it caught us all off guard how quickly it changed,” said Amy Levek, Telluride’s former mayor who now heads the Trust for Community Housing. “We have been dealing with gentrification and people buying and renovating houses for years. But it’s been a gradual process and now it’s just wham. Everything is changing so quickly. It’s just so fluid right now as far as what people want and what people are willing to pay.”

The Colorado Sun

As more urbanites flee to Colorado’s high country, home prices rise, inventories fall and rents soar. And that spells trouble for locals looking for homes near their ski-town jobs.

coloradosun.com

Record demand for Colorado resort homes is further pinching affordable housing for locals

As more urbanites flee to Colorado’s high country, home prices rise, inventories fall and rents soar. And that spells trouble for locals looking for homes near their ski-town jobs.As more urbanites flee to Colorado’s high country, home prices rise, inventories fall and rents soar. And that spells trouble for locals looking for homes near their ski-town jobs.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "Stella Yu, the artist and educator who dreamed up the...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Stella Yu, the artist and educator who dreamed up the project, said she hopes society doesn’t forget people like Eloriaga. By pasting faces of those affected, the city may see the pandemic’s impact with clearer eyes.

“I want people to remember that this is real. That not just this family has lost somebody that they love, but it’s a big loss to our community, to humanity,” Yu said.

To date, over 300 people have died of the disease in Denver. The virus has killed almost 900,00...0 people worldwide."

Denverite

See MoreA COVID-19 portrait project aims to keep those lost from being forgottenThere’s a bucket of glue waiting for you at Redline Gallery if you want to paste your own portrait on the growing wall of victims, survivors and front line workers.A COVID-19 portrait project aims to keep those lost from being forgottenThere’s a bucket of glue waiting for you at Redline Gallery if you want to paste your own portrait on the growing wall of victims, survivors and front line workers.See more at DENVERITE.COM
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: “Denver’s ballots will be mailed at a first-class rate this...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Denver’s ballots will be mailed at a first-class rate this fall, giving them a higher priority in the eyes of the U.S. Postal Service to ensure timely delivery during the November election, city Clerk and Recorder Paul López announced Thursday.”

Denverite

Most people use drop boxes to return ballots, but the city’s Clerk and Record has officially made the ballots a higher priority for the postal service.

denverite.com

Your mail ballot in Denver just got a first-class upgrade

Most people use drop boxes to return ballots, but the city’s Clerk and Record has officially made the ballots a higher priority for the postal service.Most people use drop boxes to return ballots, but the city’s Clerk and Record has officially made the ballots a higher priority for the postal service.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: “In a recent Brookings Institution report, Michael Seman, a...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“In a recent Brookings Institution report, Michael Seman, a faculty member at Colorado State University’s LEAP Institute for the Arts, argued for federal recovery measures that include substantial support for arts, cultural, and creative groups, as they do for other impacted industries.”

The Colorado Sun

In light of the pandemic and resulting unemployment for creative workers, more than a few influential arts advocates have floated the idea of a New Deal for the arts.

coloradosun.com

Can government investment in the arts help lift Colorado, the U.S. out of the economy’s coronavirus slump?

In light of the pandemic and resulting unemployment for creative workers, more than a few influential arts advocates have floated the idea of a New Deal for the arts.In light of the pandemic and resulting unemployment for creative workers, more than a few influential arts advocates have floated the idea of a New Deal for the arts.

item.title: "The U.S. economy added 1.4 million jobs in August, sending...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The U.S. economy added 1.4 million jobs in August, sending the unemployment rate below 10 percent for the first time since March, a glimmer of good news as the pandemic continues its march across the country."

Washington Post

The unemployment rate fell to 8.4 percent. The improvement in the August jobs report is good news for the economy, which has been showing signs of a rebound from the recession that began with business closures aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus.

washingtonpost.com

Economy added 1.4 million jobs in August, and the unemployment rate fell below 10 percent

The unemployment rate fell to 8.4 percent. The improvement in the August jobs report is good news for the economy, which has been showing signs of a rebound from the recession that began with business closures aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus.The unemployment rate fell to 8.4 percent. The improvement in the August jobs report is good news for the economy, which has been showing signs of a rebound from the recession that began with business closures aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: "CU Boulder estimates it will have to cut an additional $17...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"CU Boulder estimates it will have to cut an additional $17 million from this year’s budget after administrators slashed it in anticipation of financial shortfalls due to COVID-19."

The Denver Post

University of Colorado Boulder leaders expect decreased enrollment to exacerbate the steep budget cuts already levied upon the largest university in the state as the pandemic continues to wreak hav…

denverpost.com

CU Boulder enrollment drops in face of COVID-19, administrators warn more budget cuts are looming

University of Colorado Boulder leaders expect decreased enrollment to exacerbate the steep budget cuts already levied upon the largest university in the state as the pandemic continues to wreak hav…University of Colorado Boulder leaders expect decreased enrollment to exacerbate the steep budget cuts already levied upon the largest university in the state as the pandemic continues to wreak hav…

item.title: "We were all looking for a more curated space to find Black...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"We were all looking for a more curated space to find Black businesses,” said Kazadi, who works for Comcast Business and is a writer for Christain lifestyle magazine Back2Basics. “We thought, let’s provide a platform that anyone could use.”

Now, two months after Blackout Day 2020, the BBLK app has arrived."

The Denver Post

The point of the BBLK app isn’t to eclipse businesses owned by people of other races, its co-founder said. It’s about providing an easier avenue to support Black-owned businesses more f…

denverpost.com

Denver entrepreneurs launch app designed to be “a GPS to find Black-owned businesses”

The point of the BBLK app isn’t to eclipse businesses owned by people of other races, its co-founder said. It’s about providing an easier avenue to support Black-owned businesses more f…The point of the BBLK app isn’t to eclipse businesses owned by people of other races, its co-founder said. It’s about providing an easier avenue to support Black-owned businesses more f…

item.title: “Really since about mid-July, we’ve been at a good place,”...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Really since about mid-July, we’ve been at a good place,” Herlihy said.

But this optimism wasn’t exactly the reason Herlihy and other public health experts held a virtual news conference on Wednesday. Instead, the reason for the news conference was to warn how quickly another spike in cases could erupt if Coloradans throw caution to the wind this coming Labor Day weekend."

The Colorado Sun

The latest modeling data in Colorado shows problems ahead if Labor Day celebrations are like those for the Fourth of July

coloradosun.com

Colorado’s coronavirus cases are back under control, but could Labor Day and school reopenings cause a new spike?

The latest modeling data in Colorado shows problems ahead if Labor Day celebrations are like those for the Fourth of JulyThe latest modeling data in Colorado shows problems ahead if Labor Day celebrations are like those for the Fourth of July
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "When the statue of a Union soldier that stood on the west...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"When the statue of a Union soldier that stood on the west side of the state Capitol was toppled and defaced by protesters in June, it did more than reignite a long-running conversation about public monuments and their meaning. It also started a chain reaction that could add new dimension and additional context to the remembrance of Colorado’s complex history."

The Colorado Sun

The damaged statue now appears headed for a stay at History Colorado. Will a memorial to the Sand Creek massacre rise in its place?

coloradosun.com

When the Union soldier fell at the Colorado Capitol, it may have started a chain reaction

The damaged statue now appears headed for a stay at History Colorado. Will a memorial to the Sand Creek massacre rise in its place?The damaged statue now appears headed for a stay at History Colorado. Will a memorial to the Sand Creek massacre rise in its place?
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "In recent weeks the standard wordings have felt...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"In recent weeks the standard wordings have felt insufficient, and polling firms have adjusted the questions they’re asking. They’re seeking to determine which candidate’s approach resonates more — not only whether voters are truly worried that the flare-ups of urban violence will reach their homes, but also whom they blame for them and how they think they should be quelled."

The New York Times

President Trump and Joe Biden have taken starkly divergent approaches to protests and outbreaks of violence in American cities. Gauging whose messaging is more effective has proved challenging for pollsters.

nytimes.com

Which Candidate Do Voters Trust to Handle the Unrest?

President Trump and Joe Biden have taken starkly divergent approaches to protests and outbreaks of violence in American cities. Gauging whose messaging is more effective has proved challenging for pollsters.President Trump and Joe Biden have taken starkly divergent approaches to protests and outbreaks of violence in American cities. Gauging whose messaging is more effective has proved challenging for pollsters.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: “The grand plan of the Chicano movement was to start taking...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The grand plan of the Chicano movement was to start taking over these public places and making them our own,” Martinez de Luna said. “‘Takeover’s’ not the best word. But the plan was that we were going to create spaces for ourselves after the major displacement of Auraria. Displacement is our history, over and over and over.”

Denverite

Lincoln Park could become Denver’s first historic cultural district recognizing Chicano historyAnd, the west Denver neighborhood could become the city’s first historic culture district since 2002.Lincoln Park could become Denver’s first historic cultural district recognizing Chicano historyAnd, the west Denver neighborhood could become the city’s first historic culture district since 2002.See more at DENVERITE.COM
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "Following guidance from the Metro Denver Partnership for...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Following guidance from the Metro Denver Partnership for Health, the district is now eyeing three key figures to determine the safety of welcoming students and staff back to school, which are featured on a publicly available dashboard on DPS’ website.

They include:

- The number of COVID-19 cases in Denver County, based on a two-week average per 100,000 residents...
- Trends in COVID-19 cases, meaning the degree to which cases are increasing or decreasing in Denver County
- And the test positivity rate — the percentage of COVID-19 tests that come back positive — in Denver County"

The Denver Post

See MoreDenver Public Schools is still largely planning to have students learn online through mid-October, but a new set of COVID-related metrics are helping the district determine when it will be safe to …

denverpost.com

Here are the 3 metrics that will help determine when Denver students can return to the classroom

item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "Tenants will still be on the hook for all this unpaid rent...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Tenants will still be on the hook for all this unpaid rent when the moratorium expires Dec. 31. And landlords in the meantime may find it increasingly hard to make repairs and cover the mortgage. For this reason, even advocates cheering the moratorium call it a half measure. And landlord groups warn it could destabilize the housing market even more."

The New York Times

Renters receive more relief, but there’s a looming problem for landlords, especially those who own just a few properties.

nytimes.com

Why an Eviction Ban Alone Won’t Prevent a Housing Crisis

Renters receive more relief, but there’s a looming problem for landlords, especially those who own just a few properties.Renters receive more relief, but there’s a looming problem for landlords, especially those who own just a few properties.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "Colorado’s county clerks have worried the coronavirus...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Colorado’s county clerks have worried the coronavirus pandemic would leave them short on election workers, since the older folks who tend to sign up to run voting centers, process mail-in ballots and verify signatures are the ones most at risk.

But other Coloradans have stepped up — in a big way.

“We’ve seen a remarkable response. We’ve have had hundreds per county,” said Pam Anderson, executive director of the Colorado County Clerks Association."

...

The Denver Post

See MoreColorado’s county clerks have worried for months that the coronavirus pandemic would leave them short on election workers. But voters are stepping up in a big way. More than 4,000 Denverites …

denverpost.com

Coloradans sign up to be election workers in record numbers, clerks say

Colorado’s county clerks have worried for months that the coronavirus pandemic would leave them short on election workers. But voters are stepping up in a big way. item.title: "Colorado will invest $2 million in federal coronavirus...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Colorado will invest $2 million in federal coronavirus relief funds in school districts trying to make sure all of their students have a reliable internet connection while learning at home."

The Colorado Sun

Broadband access is “a non-negotiable” for students and families, particularly with many learning from home, Education Commissioner Katy Anthes says.

coloradosun.com

Colorado pours $2M into internet access for families while partnering with providers like T-Mobile to expand broadband

Broadband access is “a non-negotiable” for students and families, particularly with many learning from home, Education Commissioner Katy Anthes says.Broadband access is “a non-negotiable” for students and families, particularly with many learning from home, Education Commissioner Katy Anthes says.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: “Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator....
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in order to express themselves.

However, with so much going on, racial injustice, a global pandemic, police brutality, corruption, it is hard to know where to start. The question for people who want to get involved remains the same — what can I do? However, it is not asked rhetorically. Local artists and the Curious Theatre in Denver found their answer in The Breath Project.”

303 Magazine

Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in ord…

303magazine.com

The Breath Project Gives Artists of Color the Spotlight With 8:46 Minute Performances

Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in ord…Art records a moment in time through the eyes of its creator. In a time when social injustice is rampant but the fight against it has poured out into the streets, many turn to their artistry in ord…
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "As experts across the country focus their attention on the...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"As experts across the country focus their attention on the question, Colorado has ramped up its own effort to create an ethical and logistical framework to distribute the vaccine. The goal is for the process to be rational, fair, transparent and equitable. But, with so many unknowns surrounding the virus, research and vaccine politics still in play, that’s a lot harder than it sounds."

The Colorado Sun

The priority system will depend on a number of factors that doctors and scholars can’t yet assess

coloradosun.com

Months before its arrival, Colorado tries to answer the question: Who should get the coronavirus vaccine first?

The priority system will depend on a number of factors that doctors and scholars can’t yet assessThe priority system will depend on a number of factors that doctors and scholars can’t yet assess
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.”

- 5280 Magazine

...

Styling: LILFRESHSAM
